advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the pictured floppy drives have never been released.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Imagine a microcomputer with all the design savvy, ruggedness, and sophistication of the best minicomputers.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by dozens of interface, memory and processor option boards. One that can be Interfaced to an indefinite number of peripheral devices including dual floppy discs, CRTs, line printers, cassette recorders, video displays, paper tape readers, teleprinters. plotters, and custom devices.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by extensive software IncludIng Extended BASIC, DISK BASIC, DOS and a complete library of business, developmental, and Industrial programs.<br> ImagIne a microcomputer that will do everything a mini will do, only at a fraction of the cost.<br> You are imagining the Altair 8800b. The Altair 8800b is here today, and it may very welt be the mainframe of the 70's. <br><br> The Altair 8800b is a second generation design of the most popular microcomputer In the field, the Altair 8800. Built around the 8800A microprocessor, the Altair 8800b is an open ended machine that is compatible with all Altair 8800 hardware and software. It can be configured to match most any system need.<br> MITS' plug-In compatible boards for the Altair 8800b now include: 4K static memory. 4K dynamic memory, 16K static memory, multi-port serial interface, multi-port parallel interface, audio cassette record interface, vectored interrupt, real time clock, PROM board, multiplexer, AID convertor, extender card, disc controller and line printer interface.<br> MITS' peripherals for the Altair 8800b include the Altair Floppy Disc, Altair Line Printer, teletypewriters, and the soon-to-be-announced Altair CRT terminal. <br><br> Introductory prices for the Altair 8800b are $840 for a kit with complete assembly instructions, and $1100 for an assembled unit. Complete documentation, membership into the Altair Users Club, subscription to "Computer Notes", access to the Altair Software Library, and a copy of Charles J. Sippi's Microcomputer Dictionary are included.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SALES CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this catalog, NEWMAN COMPUTER EXCHANGE from Ann Arbor sold various Interact packages, from $44.95 for an incomplete and inoperative 8K model, to $299.95 for a 16K system along with 30 software cassettes and a complete documentation including the service manuals set. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH (STUPID) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Family life scene in front of a complete Atmos system carefully lined up on the coffee table in the living room, with a minimum of visible cables. <br><br> The flaw?... No, it is not that it is rather difficult to use such a serious configuration for hours sitting on the floor. The flaw comes rather from the photographer who forgot to do the housework before taking the picture and left to posterity his accessories cartons right behind the low dresser.</blockquote>

computer.description:
The VIC-1001 is the first of the VIC series of computers, which includes the tremendously successful VIC-20. The VIC-1001 was only sold in Japan. As such, it includes a special character ROM and keyboard that allow the user to enter Katakana characters.
As often with Commodore, the origin of the "-1001" moniker is unclear. It might be a reference to another popular Commodore system, the PET-2001. When he introduced the VIC-1001 to the world, Jack Tramiel uttered this unforgettable sentence: "The Japanese are coming, so we must become the Japanese!" (referring to the threats of low-cost systems from Japan) He then proceeded to create one of the most popular line of micro-computers of all time.
___________
Contributors: Thomas Cont?

item.description: CMD SuperCPU||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD SUPERCPU</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SuperCPU by Creative Micro Devices is an accelerator cartridge for the Commodore 64. It contains an W65C816S processor running at 20 MHz, providing 20 times the performance of the stock 6510 processor! CMD later added a SuperRAM Card option that could include up to 16 MB of additional memory. There is also a v2 version that offers native 128 mode support (also called SuperCPU/128). It is one of the most sought-after Commodore peripherals.<p class="petitgris">Thomas Conté</p></blockquote>

CMD RAMLink||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD RAMLINK</strong></font><br><blockquote>This RAM expansion unit by Creative Micro Devices was intended to be used as a RAM drive to accelerate disk access. It is externally powered, and thus will preserve the data even when the computer is turned off.<p class="petitgris">Thomas Conté</p></blockquote>

Floppy disk unit 1540-1541||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DISK UNIT 1540-1541</strong></font><br><blockquote>It is connected to the C64 via a serial link.<br> It is very very slow and can store 170 kb per disk.</blockquote>

Quick Data Drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUICK DATA DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Cheaper and faster than diskettes.</b> <br><br> This Quick Data Drive from Dean Electronics is dedicated to Commodore 64 and <$252$>Vic 20</a> systems. It uses a special tape called 'Wafer', of 16, 64 or 128 Kb capacity. This wafer was also used by a product marketed for the <$223$>Sinclair Spectrum</a>, called Wafadrive. Various tests proved that the Q.D.D. was approximately 20 times faster than a normal cassette recorder and 2 or 3 times faster than the Commodore 1541 disk drive. The reason : data transfer routines (called QOS) much more efficient than those of Commodore, and a file management operating system (FMU) much more modern and powerful. <br><br> The Q.D.D. is however not more than an advanced tape recorder using a magnetic tape, and the delay to access a specific file still remains higher than with a normal disk drive. Despite its qualities, the Q.D.D. did not meet success because most C64 software was sold on disks or tapes and users had to acquire both Commodore peripherals before investing in a third powerful storage system.</blockquote>

CMD HD-20|||20Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD HD-20</strong></font><br><strong>> 20Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a hard drive for the C64 or 128. SWAP-Devicenumber-Buttons let the HD become drive 8 or 9. It can create sub-directories and partitions, including 1541 emulation.</blockquote>
Model 1525||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MODEL 1525</strong></font><br><blockquote>It can print all the semi graphic characters of the C64. (30 characters per second) </blockquote>

computer.name: VIC-1001
computer.ports: 1 joystick port, 1 user port, 1 serial port, 1 cartrige port, CBM DIN video output, tape interface
computer.ram: 5 KB (3583 bytes free), expandable up to 21 KB
computer.vram: Screen memory shared with regular RAM
